html: Show that the acceleration of any object down a frictionless incline that makes an angle \( \theta \) with the horizontal is \( a = g \sin \theta \). (Note that this acceleration is independent of mass.)

To show that the acceleration of an object down an incline is \( a = g(\sin \theta - \mu_k \cos \theta) \), we start by analyzing the forces acting on the object. The forces acting on the object are:
  • The gravitational force \( \mathbf{F}_g = mg \)
  • The normal force \( \mathbf{N} \)
  • The kinetic friction force \( \mathbf{f}_k = \mu_k \mathbf{N} \)
 We decompose the gravitational force into components parallel and perpendicular to the incline:
  • Parallel component: \( F_{\parallel} = mg \sin \theta \)
  • Perpendicular component: \( F_{\perp} = mg \cos \theta \)
 The normal force \( \mathbf{N} \) is equal in magnitude and opposite in direction to the perpendicular component of the gravitational force: \[ N = mg \cos \theta \] The kinetic friction force \( \mathbf{f}_k \) is given by: \[ f_k = \mu_k N = \mu_k (mg \cos \theta) \] The net force \( \mathbf{F}_{\text{net}} \) acting on the object along the incline is the difference between the parallel component of the gravitational force and the kinetic friction force: \[ F_{\text{net}} = F_{\parallel} - f_k = mg \sin \theta - \mu_k (mg \cos \theta) \] Using Newton's second law \( F = ma \), we can express the net force as: \[ ma = mg \sin \theta - \mu_k (mg \cos \theta) \] Dividing both sides of the equation by \( m \) to solve for the acceleration \( a \): \[ a = g (\sin \theta - \mu_k \cos \theta) \] This shows that the acceleration \( a \) is independent of the mass \( m \) of the object. When the friction coefficient \( \mu_k \) is zero, the expression reduces to: \[ a = g \sin \theta \] which is the acceleration of an object down a frictionless incline.

<pl-hint data-type="text" level="1">
        To show that the acceleration of an object down an incline is \( a = g(\sin \theta - \mu_k \cos \theta) \), we start by analyzing the forces acting on the object.
    </pl-hint>
<pl-number-input answers-name="gMoon" comparison="sigfig" digits="3" label="g (Moon) (in {{params.unitsAccel}})"></pl-number-input>

<pl-answer correct="true">The ultimate determinant of the truth in science is empirical evidence. Action at a distance was ultimately accepted because it was supported by experimental observations and mathematical consistency.</pl-answer>
<pl-answer correct="false">The ultimate determinant of the truth in science is logical consistency. Action at a distance was ultimately accepted because it was logically consistent with existing theories.</pl-answer>
<pl-answer correct="false">The ultimate determinant of the truth in science is philosophical reasoning. Action at a distance was ultimately accepted because it aligned with philosophical principles.</pl-answer>
<pl-answer correct="false">The ultimate determinant of the truth in science is consensus among scientists. Action at a distance was ultimately accepted because most scientists agreed on it.</pl-answer>
</pl-multiple-choice>

<pl-computation-panel>
<pl-computation>
<pl-formula name="orbital_angular_momentum">
      L_orbit = params.moon_mass * params.orbital_radius * params.orbital_velocity
    </pl-formula>
<pl-formula name="rotational_angular_momentum">
      I = (2/5) * params.moon_mass * (params.moon_radius^2)
      omega = (2 * Math.PI) / params.rotational_period
      L_rotation = I * omega
    </pl-formula>
</pl-computation>
</pl-computation-panel>

      I = (2/5) * params.moon_mass * (params.moon_radius^2)
      omega = (2 * Math.PI) / params.rotational_period
      L_rotation = I * omega
    </pl-formula>
</pl-computation>

<pl-formula name="orbital_angular_momentum">

</pl-output-panel>

<pl-mca-adaptive>
<pl-checkbox answers-name="assoc_law" inline="true" weight="1">
<pl-answer choice-name="opt0" correct="true"> $(a + b) + c = a + (b + c)$ </pl-answer>
<pl-answer choice-name="opt1" correct="false"> $(a \times b) + c = a \times (b + c)$ </pl-answer>
<pl-answer choice-name="opt2" correct="false"> $(a + b) \times c = a + (b \times c)$ </pl-answer>
<pl-answer choice-name="opt3" correct="false"> $(a \times b) \times c = a + (b \times c)$ </pl-answer>
</pl-checkbox>
</pl-mca-adaptive>

<pl-hhint data-type="text" level="2">
        The initial momentum of the system is given by the momentum of the moving sled and the child. Since the second sled is stationary, its initial momentum is zero. The initial momentum \( p_{initial} \) is:
        \[
        p_{initial} = m_{sled} \times v_{initial} + m_{child} \times v_{initial}
        \]
        where \( m_{sled} \) is the mass of one sled, \( m_{child} \) is the mass of the child, and \( v_{initial} \) is the initial speed of the child and the sled.
    
<pl-hint data-type="text" level="3">
        After the collision, the two sleds lock together and move with a common speed \( v_{final} \). The total mass of the two sleds is \( 2 \times m_{sled} \). The final momentum \( p_{final} \) is:
        \[
        p_{final} = (2 \times m_{sled}) \times v_{final}
        \]
    </pl-hint>
<pl-hint data-type="text" level="4">
        By the conservation of momentum, we have:
        \[
        p_{initial} = p_{final}
        \]
        Substituting the expressions for \( p_{initial} \) and \( p_{final} \), we get:
        \[
        m_{sled} \times v_{initial} + m_{child} \times v_{initial} = (2 \times m_{sled}) \times v_{final}
        \]
    </pl-hint>
<pl-hint data-type="text" level="5">
        Since the sleds are identical, \( m_{sled} = m_{child} \). Therefore, the equation simplifies to:
        \[
        2 \times m_{sled} \times v_{initial} = 2 \times m_{sled} \times v_{final}
        \]
        Dividing both sides by \( 2 \times m_{sled} \), we get:
        \[
        v_{final} = v_{initial} / 2
        \]
    </pl-hint>
<pl-hint data-type="text" level="6">
        Substituting the given initial speed \( v_{initial} = {{params.v_initial}} \) {{params.unitsSpeed}}, we find the final speed of the two sleds:
        \[
        v_{final} = \frac{{{{params.v_initial}}}}{2} = {{correct_answers.v_final}} {{params.unitsSpeed}}
        \]
    </pl-hint>
</pl-hhint>
